newsitem.title: USA: Oregon voters approve measure to cap taxes - paper.
newsitem.headline: Oregon voters approve measure to cap taxes - paper.

text.p: Oregon voters approved a controversial ballot measure that would limit state property taxes but require the legislature to replace revenues lost by local schools, according to a published report Wednesday.
Ballot measure 50 received 56 percent support with 85 percent of the statewide results counted, according to the Oregonian newspaper.

Measure 50 calls for a 17 percent tax cut and a three percent growth cap, similar to measure 47, which state voters approved last November. Oregon lawmakers introduced measure 50 after questions were raised about the legality of measure 47.
* Roll assessed property values back to 90 percent of their 1995-1996 level.
* Cap assessed values, and restrict their growth to no more than 3.0 percent per year.
* Provide a tax reduction statewide of about 17 percent on operational levies.
* Maintain the funding priorities for schools and public safety. Measure 50 requires the legislature to replace property tax revenues lost by local schools.
* Retain the existing property tax rate limitation of $5 per $1,000 of value for schools and $10 per $1,000 of value for other local governments.
* Require votes for new taxes to be held on general election days, or when over 50 percent of eligible voters turn out and over 50 percent vote 'yes.'
* Exempt taxes levied to pay bonds if the bonds were approved by voters.
